p: A continuous search for potential new strains for large-scale production of these pigments are still advancing as the current major strains are still limited to a few species, namely, Spirulina platensis, Haematococcus pluvialis and Chlorella sp. Singh et al. [ 136] discovered Asterarcys quadricellulare PUMCC 5.1.1 strain, a green microalga with a promising characteristic for carotenoid production while Kaushal et al. [ 137] reported a new cyanobacterium Nodularia sphaerocarpa PUPCCC 420.1 which produces phycobiliprotein and reckoned as a good candidate for production at commercial scale.
